title: Fix race condition for skylet daemon
body:
Closes #745. Changed the behavior of the status update in skylet daemon: only update the status of the jobs that are submitted more than 2 seconds ago (need to be tuned based on heuristics), to make sure `ray job` has been correctly updated.

The problem is hard to reproduce, so I chose a reasonable gap (2 seconds) for the job status update.

title: Fix the setup progress bar and conda confirmation message
body:
Closes #735 and #673.
Main changes:
1. Remove the console.status for setup as that will break the progress bar.
2. Let the setup not go through the streaming output processing as the process can only print the line that ends with `\n` or `\r`, but the conda confirmation line, e.g. `Remove existing environment (y/[n])?`, does not end with `\n` or `\r`.

**Side-effect**: (Need to decide whether the benefit worth it)
1. The bash warning will be shown at the beginning of the setup:
```
bash: cannot set terminal process group (42759): Inappropriate ioctl for device
bash: no job control in this shell
```

Tried:
1. Change the non_interactive mode for ssh from `ssh -T` to `ssh -T -i -tt`, suggested in the comment. (not working)
2. Change the order of the `bash --login -c -i` to `bash -i -l -c`. (not working, [ref](https://github.com/sindresorhus/alfred-npms/issues/1))
3. `tee >(grep -v 'bash: ....'  --line-buffered >> {log_path})`. (This will behave similarly as our own stream processing not showing the confirmation line).
4. Set the non_interactive (`-T`) mode for ssh to interactive (`-tt`) mode. This will cause that the ctrl-c will be caught by the remote process rather than directly killing the sky program, and each ctrl-c will only kill one command, e.g. `conda create -n mypytorch`, and the next command will continue running, e.g. `conda install -n mypytorch pytorch`. Also, it will make the multi-node launching a mess, as the user have to press multiple ctrl-c to stop all the setups on every node (with the non_interactive mode, one ctrl-c is enough).

Tested:
- [x] `examples/run_smoke_tests.sh`

title: Delete aws security group
body:
This PR prevents security group leaks.

Because we cannot start deleting security group before the instances are deleted, this increases teardown time.

It takes 48.812s to terminate a single AWS node after this PR. Before:  19.163s.

It takes 48.655s to terminate 4 AWS nodes after this PR. Before:  25.404s.

Actually with more nodes, the termination time does not go up, which is actually reasonable: the instance deletion latency hides the latency of the original `sky down`.

title: Specify region in resources
body:
Closes #695. Added a region field in the `Resources`.

BEHAVIOR CHANGE:
1. If a cluster is in INIT mode and re-launched, the failover will be disabled, i.e. only try to launch it on the previously failed region. 
  Previous: If a cluster is in INIT mode and re-launched, the failover will be enabled within a cloud, i.e. try to failover on the previously failed cloud. 
  Comment: this does not affect much of the normal use case, as our cluster is unlikely to be in `INIT` mode unless:
      1. the user ctrl-C during the `ray up`
      1. our ray yaml file has some bug.

Tested:
- [x] Backward compatibility: `sky launch -c min ./examples/minimal.yaml` with the previous version. `sky status/sky exec/sky launch` with the current version.
- [x] `sky launch -c min --region us-west-2 ./examples/minimal.yaml`, `sky exec min ./examples/minimal.yaml`
- [x] `sky launch -c min --region us-west-2 ./examples/minimal.yaml`, `sky exec min ./examples/minimal.yaml` with `resources: region: us-east-1`. Failed as expected.
- [x] `sky launch -c min --region us-west-2 ./examples/minimal.yaml`, `sky launch -c min --region us-west-1 ./examples/minimal.yaml`. Failed as expected.
- [x] `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh`

title: Change default gpu from K80 to T4
body:
As discussed in https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/700, T4 seems to be a better choice as the default gpu node. Please comment below if you have any additional thoughts.

Copied from the discussion.
> Speaking of the default gpu node type, should we consider changing it to g4dn.xlarge? It can be cheaper (0.900 vs 0.526, tho host memory size is smaller) and T4 is a newer generation than K80. (remember that we had to choose images with older nvidia driver in order to support K80). It supports mixed precision and seems to be more cost efficient than K80 ([details here](https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/ai-machine-learning/your-ml-workloads-cheaper-and-faster-with-the-latest-gpus)).

A possible issue is that `T4:1` requirement is satisfied by many VM instances on clouds so the candidate list is longer. not sure if users would like it or not.

Before:
```
(sky) weichiang@blaze:~/repos/sky$ sky gpunode
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:601] Optimizer - plan minimizing cost
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:613] Estimated cost: ~$0.2/hr
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:628] TASK     BEST_RESOURCE
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:628] gpunode  Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1})
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:648] Considered resources -> cost ($)
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:649] {Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1}): 0.22,
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:649]  AWS(p2.xlarge, {'K80': 1}): 0.9,
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:649]  GCP(n1-highmem-8, {'K80': 1}): 0.92}
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:649] 
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:665] Multiple Azure instances satisfy K80:1. The cheapest Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1}) is considered among:
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:665] ['Standard_NC6_Promo', 'Standard_NC6'].
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:665] 
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:671] To list more details, run 'sky show-gpus K80'.
```

After:
```
(sky) weichiang@blaze:~/repos/sky$ sky gpunode
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:601] Optimizer - plan minimizing cost
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:613] Estimated cost: ~$0.5/hr
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:628] TASK     BEST_RESOURCE
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:628] gpunode  AWS(g4dn.xlarge, {'T4': 1})
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:648] Considered resources -> cost ($)
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:649] {GCP(n1-highmem-8, {'T4': 1}): 0.82,
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:649]  Azure(Standard_NC4as_T4_v3, {'T4': 1}): 0.63,
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:649]  AWS(g4dn.xlarge, {'T4': 1}): 0.53}
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:649] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] Multiple AWS instances satisfy T4:1. The cheapest AWS(g4dn.xlarge, {'T4': 1}) is considered among:
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] ['g4dn.xlarge', 'g4dn.2xlarge', 'g4dn.4xlarge', 'g4dn.8xlarge', 'g4dn.16xlarge'].
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] Multiple Azure instances satisfy T4:1. The cheapest Azure(Standard_NC4as_T4_v3, {'T4': 1}) is considered among:
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] ['Standard_NC4as_T4_v3', 'Standard_NC8as_T4_v3', 'Standard_NC16as_T4_v3'].
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:671] To list more details, run 'sky show-gpus T4'.
```

title: Fix optimizer messages
body:
This PR closes #700

The fixed optimizer will 
* skip the head message (`Optimizer - plan minimizing cost`) if the search space is trivial, and
* print hourly cost when the DAG consists of a task that does not have a time estimator and does not involve any data egress.

NOTE: `sky gpunode` still prints the header message because there are three candidates (each for three cloud vendors).
```
$ sky gpunode
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:601] Optimizer - plan minimizing cost
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:613] Estimated hourly cost: ~$0.2/hr
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:628] TASK     BEST_RESOURCE
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:628] gpunode  Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1})
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:648] Considered resources -> cost ($)
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:649] {GCP(n1-highmem-8, {'K80': 1}): 0.92,
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:649]  AWS(p2.xlarge, {'K80': 1}): 0.9,
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:649]  Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1}): 0.22}
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:649] 
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:665] Multiple Azure instances satisfy K80:1. The cheapest Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1}) is considered among:
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:665] ['Standard_NC6_Promo', 'Standard_NC6'].
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:665]
```

On the other hand, `sky gpunode --cloud aws` skips the message (`Optimizer - plan minimizing cost`) since the candidate instance type is unique.
```
$ sky gpunode --cloud aws
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:613] Estimated hourly cost: ~$0.9/hr
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:628] TASK     BEST_RESOURCE
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:628] gpunode  AWS(p2.xlarge, {'K80': 1})
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:628]
```

title: Storage Subdirectory Fix
body:
Fixes #707. 

## Test
```
resources:
  cloud: aws

num_nodes: 1  

workdir: .


file_mounts:
  /my-dataset:
    source: s3://christmas-balsa/100321
    mode: COPY
  /my-dataset-1:
    source: s3://christmas-balsa
    mode: COPY

title: Fix Repeating IP in SSH Config
body:
## Description

The edge case is the following. If SSH Config already has `Host hello` (from user's prior experiments prior to installing/using Sky) and the user runs `sky launch -c hello examples/env_check.yaml`, Sky will add 
```
# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down hello` to remove)
Host 18.215.241.153
  HostName 18.215.241.153
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22
```
However, if `sky launch -c hello examples/env_check.yaml` is run multiple times, the above block is added multiple times to the config file. This is due to the fact that there is no check for this case.

## Tests

Step 1: Add this block to the Config file.
```
# Fake SSH Config
Host hallo
  HostName 59.152.136.89
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22
```
Step 2: Run `sky launch -c examples/env_check.yaml`

title: Fix GCP Lock Bug
body:
## Description

Solves #629. Launching a GCP instance and having `sudo apt/apt-get install XYZ` will error out due to lock being held by DPKG process.

Unlike in AWS or Azure, GCP does not have `lsof` or `fuser`, so a more brute force method is used to identify the process that is holding the lock: 
`sudo kill -9  'sudo find /proc/*/fd -ls | grep /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend | grep -oP '/proc/\d+' | tail -n 1 | grep -oP '\d+'' || true;`
This line above goes through the process folder and through a bunch of regex, finds the process ID that is holding the lock. 


Last but not least, restarting DPKG has errors on GCP, and the work around is uninstalling and reinstalling `google-cloud-sdk`.

## Test
The following YAML passes without erorrs:
```
name: apt-lock-bug
resources:
  cloud: gcp
  instance_type: n1-highmem-2
setup: |
  sudo apt install cargo
  sudo apt-get install libosmesa6-dev
```

title: Storage mounting
body:
This PR implements sky storage mounting, which allows us to directly mount S3/GCS buckets without having to copy their contents. This also enables writing to mounts, effectively allowing users to provision an infinitely scaling networked file system shared among worker nodes.

More details are in the [proposal](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uVNTWk44lvzPFTr9flfPZrs-sT6fiKlqnAPROprwEmU/).

# Major changes

## `sky.Storage`
* Added object store mounting support for Store objects. 
* Removed deprecated storage/storage_mount YAML API.
* Add `StorageError` family of exceptions for more effective error handling.
* Added distributed training example with automatic checkpointing and restore (thanks @michaelzhiluo and @michaelvll)


## Validation logic
* All storage objects must now satisfy the following validation logic:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4416605/160348903-38743796-17d3-480c-a51a-7694deac299f.png)
* Validation logic moved from from_yaml to Storage object.

## Interaction with Global User State
* Only objects managed by sky are now added to the global user state. 
* When loading from `global_user_state`, self.source no longer needs to match the source in global_user_state.
* Added a `sync_on_reconstruction` flag to Storage class to specify whether to (re)upload source when the Storage object is reconstructed from `global_user_state` or not. Useful to set this to False when e.g. when reconstructing for deletion.


## Refactoring
* Refactored `Storage.get_or_copy_to_s3/gcs()` to `.add_store(StoreType.S3/GCS)`
* Rename `force_stores` to `store` in YAML and change it from List[str] to str (single store only).
* Rename `StorageType` to `StoreType`
* Removed unused arg `cloud_to_remote_file_mounts` in `backend.sync_file_mounts()` and added `storage_mounts` as an arg
* Refactor cloud_vm_ray_backend.sync_file_mounts() to also execute storage mounts.
* Removed deprecated storage API from YAML

## TODO:
- [x] Add tests for sky.Storage
- [x] Add more examples (distributed counting example to demonstrate the use of shared FS)
- [x] Update documentation
- [ ] GCS Mounting with gcsfuse (separate PR)
- [ ] `sky storage mount` for local mounting on laptop (separate PR)


## Tested:
- [x] Smoke tests
- [x] New storage tests

title: Auto stop for cluster
body:
This PR enables the auto-stopping feature for the clusters. [Design Doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1nBoT9k7jcDcXVUkcpYFmp0nikaRV-aDe2ZufVWIgOVA/edit#)

Main Changes:
1. `sky autostop cluster-name -i 30`, auto-stop the cluster after 30 minutes without activities.
2. Refactor the skylet daemon with events.
3. Add autostop event in skylet.
4. Indicate the auto stop status in `sky status`
5. Update the status of the cluster autostopped

New API:
1. `sky autostop cluster_name1 cluster_name2`: cluster will stop as soon as the cluster is idle
2. `sky autostop cluster_name1 cluster_name2 -i t`: cluster will stop after t minutes of inactivity.
3.  `sky autostop cluster_name1 cluster_name2 --cancel`: cancel the autostop on the cluster_name.
4. `sky status --refresh`: refresh the status for auto-stopped cluster.

Problem:
1. `sky status` will be slower if one of the clusters set autostop.
```
(sky-dev) ➜  sky-experiment-dev (auto-stop) time sky status                                                            
NAME               LAUNCHED     RESOURCES                 STATUS  AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                                    
test-auto-azure-4  21 mins ago  4x Azure(Standard_D8_v4)  INIT    -         sky launch -c test-auto-azure-4 ...        
test-auto-4        15 mins ago  4x GCP(n1-highmem-8)      UP      -         sky launch -c test-auto-4 --cloud gcp ...  
sky status  1.31s user 0.33s system 213% cpu 0.767 total

(sky-dev) ➜  sky-experiment-dev (auto-stop) time sky status --refresh
NAME               LAUNCHED     RESOURCES                 STATUS  AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                                    
test-auto-azure-4  21 mins ago  4x Azure(Standard_D8_v4)  INIT    -         sky launch -c test-auto-azure-4 ...        
test-auto-4        15 mins ago  4x GCP(n1-highmem-8)      UP      0 min     sky launch -c test-auto-4 --cloud gcp ...  
sky status  3.42s user 0.84s system 97% cpu 4.369 total
```
5. `sky status` will be set to STOPPED before all the nodes are stopped. (expected)

TODO:
- [x] Add testing
- [x] Add document

Tested:
- [x] Configure auto-stopping
- [x] Auto-stop after idle_minutes
- [x] restart cluster will reset auto-stop setting
- [x] `sky status` when remote instance is stopped by auto-stopping
- [x] `sky start` after stopped by auto-stopping
- [x] run the following commands for auto-stopped clusters:
  - ~~sky queue~~
  - ~~sky status~~
  -  ~~sky autostop cluster_name -i 0~~: correctly skipped
  - ~~sky exec cluster_name -- gpustat~~
  - ~~sky launch -c cluster_name yaml~~
  - ~~sky logs~~
- [x] Rendered locally

body:
#621 added an assertion to to_provision, which will cause the second `sky launch` failing, as the error below. This PR fix this problem by moving the assertion out.
```
(sky) ➜  sky-experiments (fix-ray-job-fail-status) sky launch -y -c min ./examples/minimal.yaml                ✭ ✱
Task from YAML spec: ./examples/minimal.yaml
Running task on cluster min...
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/zhwu/OneDrive/AResource/PhD/Research/sky-computing/code/sky-experiments/sky/execution.py", line 112, in _execute
    handle = backend.provision(task,
  File "/Users/zhwu/OneDrive/AResource/PhD/Research/sky-computing/code/sky-experiments/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1245, in provision
    to_provision_config = RetryingVmProvisioner.ToProvisionConfig(
  File "/Users/zhwu/OneDrive/AResource/PhD/Research/sky-computing/code/sky-experiments/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 417, in __init__
    assert resources is not None, 'resources must be specified.'
AssertionError: resources must be specified.
```


This PR also adds `sys.exit(1)` when ray program fails, making the `ray job status` correct if the job failed.

title: ILP-based DAG Optimizer
body:
Fixes #556.

The ILP formulation can be found [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1g0Vv_ZmgDd6OAnNJ0p4zQQ-iGjYlMn66/view?usp=sharing).

This PR also includes a random DAG generator and a brute-force solver.

Tested:
* `examples/example_app.py` (cost & time)
* `tests/test_optimizer_random_dag.py` (num_tasks=10).

**NOTE: This PR adds an ILP package `pulp` into `setup.py`. You should install this package to test the new optimizer on non-chain DAGs.**

## Discussion: Do we need the DP-based optimizer?

Since the new ILP-based optimizer can be used for any Sky DAGs, it is questionable that we should continue to use the DP algorithm for chain DAGs. Here are pros and cons:

* Pros:
  * The DP algorithm is probably easier to manipulate and debug.

* Cons:
  * Not good for maintenance.

I think we can have both algorithms for now, but we should slowly deprecate the DP algorithm to reduce redundancy. WDYT?

title: Optimize backend_utils.get_node_ips(), esp. for Azure.
body:
Azure's APIs are extremely slow; as a result, `ray get-head-ip` and the like are very slow for Azure clusters.

The below is for a 1-node Azure cluster.

Before: takes 1min 14sec
```

title: Refactor DAG optimizer
body:
Closes #545.

This PR refactors the Sky DAG optimizer. This PR includes:
* breaking up the `_optimize_cost` function, which was quite long (~170 lines) and a bit hard to follow. Now the optimization process is split into multiple smaller stages/functions.
* simplifying the DP algorithm by restricting the input graphs to chain DAGs. As reported in #556, the DP algorithm is not applicable to non-chain DAGs. So I pruned out the code for non-chain DAGs.
* more clearly printing the estimated run time and estimated cost. Now the optimizer prints both estimated run time and estimated total cost.
 
  * Before:
```bash
$ python examples/example_app.py
Optimizer - plan minimizing cost (~$57.1):
```
*
  * After: 
```bash
$ python examples/example_app.py
Optimizer - plan minimizing cost
Estimated Run time: ~21.7 hr, Cost: ~$57.1
```
* fixing a bug in printing the DAG optimization result.

NOTE: the problem in #556 is not fixed by this PR. The problem will fixed by #637, which should be merged after this PR.

Tested:
* `examples/example_app.py`
* smoke tests.

Mainly fixes the logic for stale jobs when restarting the cluster. We can safely reset the jobs in progress to FAILED, if the cluster is previously stopped. title: Optimize the `sky job queue` when large amount of jobs running
body:
Closes #612. This PR optimizes the `sky job queue` time from 24 seconds to 1.4 seconds when there are 30 jobs running. (To have 30 jobs running together, we need to change the original placement_group setting of CPUs to smaller than 1 to allow more jobs than CPU cores.)

```
# With 30 jobs running
# Old sky queue
sky queue old-jq-test  0.95s user 0.27s system 5% cpu 23.932 total

# New sky queue
sky queue  0.98s user 0.25s system 86% cpu 1.422 total
```

The previous implementation will update the job status for each job when `sky queue` is called, using `ray job status`.  It will introduce significant overheads. Since our tasks will actively update their own status in the `job_table` and the job status update will only be used for dealing with the staled jobs caused by the cluster's stop and restart, it is OK to only update the status during the provision.

title: Update GCP image for OS consistency and fix GCP's spot CPU
body:
Close https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/607.

Before:
```
ubuntu@ray-k80-gcp-old-head-4b2251cf-compute:~$ lsb_release -d
Description:    Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)

ubuntu@ray-k80-gcp-old-head-4b2251cf-compute:~$ nvidia-smi
Fri Mar 18 23:51:52 2022
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| NVIDIA-SMI 470.57.02    Driver Version: 470.57.02    CUDA Version: 11.4     |
```

Now:
```
gcpuser@ray-v100-gcp-head-209ae428-compute:~$ lsb_release -d
Description:    Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS

gcpuser@ray-v100-gcp-head-209ae428-compute:~$ nvidia-smi
Sat Mar 19 00:10:33 2022       
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| NVIDIA-SMI 470.103.01   Driver Version: 470.103.01   CUDA Version: 11.4     |
```
CUDA driver version slightly upgraded but should be fine. Tested normally on K80/V100.
CUDA runtime library upgraded from 11.0 to 11.3, which seems to be the latest version we can use according to
```
gcloud compute images list         --project deeplearning-platform-release 
```

However, two changes in this PR:

1) it looks like `ssh_user=='ubuntu'` does not work with the ubuntu image `common-cu113-ubuntu-2004`. Somehow GCP failed to create an `ubuntu` account and we couldn't ssh-login to the machine. Therefore we have to change the `ssh_user` in Ray yaml to `gcpuser` to make it work..
2) @Michaelvll and I found a bug in our jinja template for GCP. It looks like `use_spot` option would not be honored when CPU node is used.

Currently Sky only supports single task per DAG. This is an initial PR to run multiple independent tasks on Sky. One application enabled by this PR is racing benchmark where each task requires different accelerators. Potentially in the future we'll support general DAG on Sky.

@WoosukKwon and I are working together to finish this PR. Feel free to leave any comments or suggestions!

```
with sky.Dag() as dag:
    task = []
    for acc in ['K80', 'V100']:
        task.append(sky.Task(run='nvidia-smi').set_resources(sky.Resources(accelerators={acc: 1})))
```
- [ ] Support YAML interface
- [ ] Cleanup output messages from different tasks
- [ ] Fix broken line breaks of messages
- [ ] Support terminating all tasks in DAG

title: Parallel runner of smoke tests.
body:
The smoke tests can be run in ~30 minutes now.
- Example output: https://gist.github.com/concretevitamin/fb29a5a70691bed45a4f05d230b1d5c8
- It's bottlenecked by (approx) the slowest test, azure-start-stop, due to Azure's APIs being very slow

Also changed tpu delete script (cc @infwinston): 
 - discovered a race condition while testing this; it does make terminating tpu_app much longer.  But the slowest to teardown is probably still azure-start-stop.
 
-----

Tests:

  * Successful scenario
    - `time python -u examples/run_smoke.py 2>&1 | tee run.log`
      - 31:23.62 total
      - except tpu_app: (1) name bug #572; (2) we don't have a way to query a job's exit code (see below)

  * Tested multiple erroneous scenarios to ensure timeouts/error reporting/handling works as expected

-----

Future TODOs / known issues
 - [x] `sky logs --status cluster 1` or the like, to query a job's exit code
 - [ ] at the end of this script, concat all .log into one file so we can view it to ensure nothing is wrong (or auto grep for error/exception etc.)
  - [x] cannot ctrl-c the terminal that launches this script -- during or after the execution.
    - workaround: kill the window; if you want to ctrl-c in the middle to interrupt the tests: just run 'sky down -a -y' (assuming you have no other clusters) in another terminal, and the tests will error out
- [x] Our logging would mess up spacing for the terminal that runs this script (related to new line replacement?) after an error occurs / or just after a while
  - workaround: pipe to a file and view
  - cc @Michaelvll - this seems fairly easy to reproduce, e.g., just run the script for a while even with just `[minimal, multi_echo]`.
- [x] (cc @suquark) Starting all tests at the same time -- without staggering -- causes wheel builds to fail. See inlined TODOs. I added the workaround of staggering the starts + allowing each test to be retried once.

For the above reasons I tentatively didn't remove `run_smoke_tests.sh` - not feeling strongly about that, though.

title: Created and handled teardown success bool
body:
Added a success variable to teardown (`sky down`) which has the following benefits:

1. Makes it more clear when `sky down` has failed from a user perspective by surfacing it as a red result

```
(sky-full) mraheja@latte:~/Sky/sky$ sky down sky-cpunode-mraheja
Terminating 1 cluster: sky-cpunode-mraheja. Proceed? [Y/n]: y
E 03-15 02:11:49 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1743] Cluster sky-cpunode-mraheja is locked by /home/mraheja/.sky/.sky-cpunode-mraheja.lock. Check to see if it is still being launched.
Terminating cluster sky-cpunode-mraheja...failed.
```

2. Prevents deletion of YAML file if `sky down` fails by early termination of `_teardown()` #570 
3. Similarly, prevents deletion of lock file if `sky down` fails
4. Similarly, prevents removal of cluster from cluster table if `sky down` fails

title: Add worker nodes to local ssh config
body:
Currently, Sky only provides access to the head node of a cluster. This PR allows the users to easily connect to the worker nodes by adding them to the local ssh config.

Now the user can ssh into the 0-th worker node of a cluster `mycluster` by:
```bash
$ ssh mycluster-worker-0
```
Of course, I believe `scp/rsync mycluster-worker-0` should work as well.

title: Fix the lock logic for provision
body:
I separate this PR from #559, since this is a bit irrelevant with that PR.

L1128-L1148 should be locked to avoid race conditions with `teardown`. 
1. `teardown` can delete the row before L1143 adds an entry, causing the cluster has a `UP` status in the DB but actually killed.
2. `teardown` can delete the cluster_yaml before the read of L1146, causing the file loading failure.
3. `teardown` can remove the ssh entry before L1147, causing an entry in ssh config but actually killed.

@mraheja Do you think it makes sense?

title: Fix prompt, add fallback retry for INIT cluster
body:
Closes #514.

Main changes:
1. Remove the prompt of creating new cluster confirmation, when the previous cluster is in INIT mode.
2. Launching cluster in INIT mode will first retry the previous region/zone and launched_resources. If that fails, sky will try to launch the cluster of the current resources requirement, as discussed in #514.

Tested:
- [x] make aws us-east-1 out-of-quota; 
  `sky launch -c fallback examples/minimal.yaml` (with 2nodes) and kill it when launching on us-east-1; 
  `sky launch -c fallback examples/minimal.yaml` (with 1node). It will correctly retry other regions with the currently requested resources.
- [x] make aws us-east-1 out-of-quota; 
  `sky launch -c fallback --gpus A100:8 examples/minimal.yaml` and kill it when launching on us-east-1; 
  `sky launch -c fallback examples/minimal.yaml`. It will correctly try the us-east-1 with A100:8 again, and then try us-east-1 with no GPU.
  ```
  NAME      LAUNCHED     RESOURCES                          COMMAND                                   STATUS  
  fallback  11 secs ago  1x AWS(p4d.24xlarge, {'A100': 8})  sky launch -c fallback --gpus=A100:8 ...  INIT
  ```
  ```
  NAME      LAUNCHED     RESOURCES           COMMAND                                         STATUS  
  fallback  18 secs ago  1x AWS(m4.2xlarge)  sky launch -c fallback ./examples/minimal.yaml  UP     
  ```
- [x] `sky launch -c fallback examples/minimal.yaml` again will not create a new instance.

title: SSH into Worker Nodes from Local
body:
## Description
This PR allows for easy access to Worker nodes from your local machine.
```
# Launch hello cluster
sky launch -c hello examples/using_file_mounts.yaml

# SSH into head node
ssh hello

# SSH into worker node 1
ssh hello-worker1
```

## Features
- [x] SSH into worker with `ssh [cluster-name]-worker[worker-index]`
- [x] Worker SSH config details are generated in `~/.sky/generated/ssh/[cluster-name]`, linked in `~/.ssh/config`

## Tests
- Launched/Downed/Started/Stopped Single and Multinode clusters in Random Order
- Tested edge case when  `[cluster-name]-worker[worker-index]` is already in `~/.ssh/config`

```
# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down test` to remove)
Include /Users/michaelluo/.sky/generated/ssh/test

# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down bbq` to remove)
Include /Users/michaelluo/.sky/generated/ssh/bbq

Host bb
  HostName 59.152.136.89
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22

# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down bbq` to remove)
Host bbq
  HostName 100.24.1.14
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22

# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down test` to remove)
Host test
  HostName 23.20.111.54
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22

```

### Caveats
- Provision step requires `get_node_ips`.

title: Fix the dpkg lock for apt install
body:
Closes #553.

After searching around, it seems that the dpkg lock-frontend is caused by the `unattended-upgrade` service activated in the ubuntu system. This package is enabled by AWS and Azure by default but disabled by GCP (checked by `systemctl status unattended-upgrades`). This PR disables the service to avoid it from holding the dpkg lock.
```
ubuntu@ip-172-31-88-116:~$ sudo lsof /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend
COMMAND    PID USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE/OFF  NODE NAME
unattende 4652 root    5uW  REG  202,1        0 60335 /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend
ubuntu@ip-172-31-88-116:~$ ps aux | grep 4652
root      4652 78.9  0.3 370688 107768 ?       Sl   05:24   0:52 /usr/bin/python3 /usr/bin/unattended-upgrade
ubuntu    5262  0.0  0.0  14864  1012 pts/1    S+   05:26   0:00 grep --color=auto 4652
```

Tested:
- [x] `sky cpunode`; the `sudo lsof /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend` has no output; `sudo apt install tree` succeeded.
- [x] `sky launch -c fm-test ./examples/using_file_mounts.yaml`

title: Revert "Simple SSH into Multi-node Workers from Local"
body:
Reverts sky-proj/sky#469

A few things we need to flesh out before shipping this feature in master:
- Fixing #550 

Also a few issues (sent to @michaelzhiluo offline) I see after launching 2 clusters,
```
sky launch -c fm2 ./examples/using_file_mounts.yaml
sky launch -c min examples/minimal.yaml
```
which results in
```
» cat ~/.ssh/config
# Generated by sky (use `sky stop/down fm2` to remove), add entries below Include clauses
Include /Users/zongheng/.sky/generated/ssh/fm2
Host *.compute-1.amazonaws.com
IdentityFile  ~/.ssh/zongheng-us-east-1.pem

# https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-with-ssh/generating-a-new-ssh-key-and-adding-it-to-the-ssh-agent#adding-your-ssh-key-to-the-ssh-agent
Host *
  AddKeysToAgent yes
  UseKeychain yes
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa

# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down min` to remove)
Host min
  HostName 3.239.209.133
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/zongheng/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22

# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down fm2` to remove)
Host fm2
  HostName 44.198.193.4
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/zongheng/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22%
```
Issues
- Change “Generated by” to “Added by”, to be consistent with the other comment.
- Put a new line between
```
Include /Users/zongheng/.sky/generated/ssh/fm2
Host *.compute-1.amazonaws.com
```
  Because the first line was added by Sky, but `Host …` line was there in my config already.
- Why do we need `add entries below Include clauses`?  Is this a hint to the user or to Sky developers?  The user shouldn’t play around with Sky-generated entries manually.  Remove?
- It’s confusing to have fm2's entries one at the top (Include), and one down below.  Can we group them together down below?
- End-of-file doesn’t have a new line. (cat the file, and you can see a % char at the end.)
